title-group.article-title: Dynamic Equilibrium with Two Stocks, Heterogeneous Investors, and Portfolio Constraints

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright © 2013 The Society for Financial Studies

abstract.p: We study dynamic equilibrium in a Lucas economy with two stocks, two heterogeneous constant relative risk aversion investors, and portfolio constraints. We focus on margin and leverage constraints, which restrict access to credit. We find a positive relationship between the amount of leverage in the economy and magnitudes of stock return correlations and volatilities. Tighter constraints generate rich patterns in correlations and volatilities, make them less countercyclical, increase risk premia proportionally to assets' margins, and increase prices of low-margin assets more than prices of high-margin assets. We derive closed-form solutions for the unconstrained case and the case of leverage constraints.

p.mixed-citation: We note that margin constraint mJo< 1 does not bind for the more risk-averse investor A in equilibrium. Consequently, the assumption that investor A is unconstrained does not result in a loss of generality. We do not consider economies with restricted participation (i.e., m; > 1), for which the analysis is complicated by singularities in the equilibrium processes because the market prices of risk explode when the economy is dominated by the constrained investor (e.g., Basak and Cuoco 1998; Chabakauri 2010). We leave this case for future research.

Similarly to Basak and Cuoco (1998) and Basak (2000,2005), it can be demonstrated that the equilibrium in this economy is equivalent to the equilibrium in an economy with a representative investor with utility m(c;A./)= max where Xt =Çv*t/Çt ■ The expressions for the relative risk aversion V and prudence n of the representative investor, given by (22), are special cases of those in Basak (2000, 2005), derived for general utility functions.
The zero-drift Dynkin operator V is defined as follows: VF=-yX oxaXJJ+y 0y„y-?-2xyaxa,— j.

Quasilinear differential equations also arise in other models with heterogeneous investors that face portfolio constraints or are unconstrained but have recursive preferences (e.g., Gârleanu and Panageas 2010; Gârleanu and Pedersen 2011; He and Krishnamurthy 2013). However, we are not aware of any existence results presented in the literature.

Cuoco (1997) and Gârleanu and Pedersen (2011) derive similar C-CAPMs, but they do not express adjustment v* in terms of observable processes. We note that our C-CAPM holds for more general preferences, multiple assets, and time-varying margins.
The procyclicality of consumption share y can be formally demonstrated by substituting ayt with v*=0 from (18) into the correlation cony(dy/,dDt) = — o~Jtootf(\ayt\\oDt\)-

We note that the choice of state variables is not unique. For example, one can use the ratio of marginal utilities A.t =(cj) yA /(c*B) yB and aggregate consumption Dt as state variables instead of consumption share y.
